metadata.description: Traditional Chinese dishes adapted to Singaporean tastes, including Cantonese, Teochew, Hokkien, Hainanese, and Hakka styles

recipes.name: Chwee Jia Bao (Water Chestnut Bun)
recipes.description: A traditional Teochew/Chinese steamed bun filled with sweet water chestnut paste. This bun is rare in modern Singapore, but was once a popular dim sum and festive treat. (Note: Authentic recipes are scarce; this is a reconstructed version based on traditional methods.)
steps: Mix flour, yeast, sugar, and warm water to form a dough. Knead until smooth, cover, and let rise for 1 hour.
Meanwhile, cook chopped water chestnuts with sugar and oil in a pan. Add cornstarch slurry and cook until thickened. Cool completely.
Punch down dough and divide into 6 pieces. Flatten each, fill with water chestnut mixture, and seal into a bun shape.
Place buns on parchment squares, cover, and let rise 20 minutes.
Steam over high heat for 12-15 minutes until fluffy and cooked through. Serve warm.
tips: Use fresh water chestnuts for best texture and sweetness.
Buns can be frozen after steaming and reheated by steaming again.
If you have a family recipe, use that for the most authentic result!
recipes.source: Reconstructed from traditional Teochew/Chinese methods and Singaporean food history sources.
recipes.origin: Teochew/Chinese community in Singapore; a rare but nostalgic steamed bun once found at dim sum and festive tables.

recipes.name: Kong Ba Bao (Braised Pork Belly Bun)
recipes.description: A beloved Hokkien/Teochew dish in Singapore, featuring melt-in-your-mouth pork belly braised in soy sauce, spices, and aromatics, served in a fluffy steamed bun with pickled mustard greens. A festive and hawker favorite.
steps: Blanch pork belly in boiling water for 5 minutes. Drain and cut into thick slices.
In a pot, caramelize rock sugar in a little oil. Add pork belly and sear until lightly browned.
Add soy sauces, Shaoxing wine, star anise, cinnamon, cloves, garlic, ginger, and water. Bring to a boil, then cover and simmer for 1.5-2 hours until pork is tender and sauce is rich.

For buns: Mix flour, yeast, sugar, baking powder, water, and oil to form a dough. Knead until smooth, cover, and let rise 1 hour. Divide into 6-8 pieces, shape into ovals, fold over parchment, and let rise 20 minutes. Steam for 10 minutes until fluffy.
For pickled mustard greens: Stir-fry with sugar and oil until fragrant.
To serve: Open each bun, add a slice of braised pork belly, a spoonful of sauce, and some pickled mustard greens. Enjoy warm.
tips: Use skin-on pork belly for the most authentic texture.
Buns and pork can be made ahead and reheated by steaming.
Pickled mustard greens add a tangy contrast to the rich pork.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Hokkien/Teochew home cooks.
recipes.origin: Hokkien and Teochew communities in Singapore; a festive and hawker favorite, especially during celebrations.

recipes.name: Wonton Mee (Wantan Mee)
recipes.description: A beloved Singaporean and Malaysian noodle dish featuring springy egg noodles tossed in a savory soy sauce mixture, served with choy sum, char siu (Chinese BBQ pork), and delicate pork wontons, garnished with pickled green chillies.
instructions: Mix ground pork/chicken with salt, white pepper, and chives. Place a small amount in each wonton wrapper, moisten edges, fold and seal.
Combine all sauce ingredients in a serving bowl and set aside.
Bring two pots of salted water to a boil. In one, cook noodles for about 1 minute (or as per package), then drain and toss in the sauce bowl.
In the second pot, cook wontons for 3-5 minutes until they float. In the last 30 seconds, add choy sum to blanch. Remove both.
Toss noodles thoroughly in sauce, adding a splash of noodle water if needed.
Top noodles with char siu, wontons, and choy sum. Garnish with pickled green chillies and a dash of white pepper. Serve immediately.
recipes.source: Adapted from The Muddled Pantry and Nyonya Cooking, both reputable sources for Southeast Asian cuisine.

recipes.name: Har Cheong Gai (Prawn Paste Chicken)
recipes.description: A Singapore zi char and hawker favorite: crispy, juicy fried chicken wings marinated in fermented prawn paste, garlic, and spices. Served with lime and chili dip.
preparation: Mix marinade ingredients. Coat chicken wings and marinate at least 4 hours or overnight.
Heat oil in a wok or deep fryer. Coat wings in extra cornstarch if desired. Fry in batches until golden and crisp (about 8 minutes per batch). Drain on paper towels.
Serve hot with lime wedges and chili dip.
tips: Marinate overnight for best flavor.
Use potato starch for extra crispiness if desired.
recipes.source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, The MeatMen, and Singapore zi char stalls.
steps: Mix marinade ingredients. Coat chicken wings and marinate at least 4 hours or overnight.
Heat oil in a wok or deep fryer. Coat wings in extra cornstarch if desired. Fry in batches until golden and crisp (about 8 minutes per batch). Drain on paper towels.
Serve hot with lime wedges and chili dip.

recipes.name: Claypot Rice (with Chicken and Chinese Sausage)
recipes.description: A classic Cantonese-Singaporean dish: fragrant rice cooked in a claypot with marinated chicken, Chinese sausage, mushrooms, and salted fish. Finished with a savory soy sauce and crispy rice crust.
preparation: Marinate chicken with marinade ingredients for at least 30 minutes.
Drain soaked rice and add to claypot with 2.5 cups water. Bring to a boil, then simmer 10 minutes.
Arrange chicken, mushrooms, sausage, ginger, and salted fish on top. Cover and cook 20–25 minutes on low heat until chicken is cooked and rice is tender.
Mix sauce ingredients and pour over rice. Garnish with spring onions. Serve hot, scraping up crispy rice crust.
tips: Use a heavy claypot for best results.
Add salted fish for authentic flavor, but it can be omitted.
recipes.source: Adapted from The Woks of Life, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore hawker stalls.
steps: Marinate chicken with marinade ingredients for at least 30 minutes.
Drain soaked rice and add to claypot with 2.5 cups water. Bring to a boil, then simmer 10 minutes.
Arrange chicken, mushrooms, sausage, ginger, and salted fish on top. Cover and cook 20–25 minutes on low heat until chicken is cooked and rice is tender.
Mix sauce ingredients and pour over rice. Garnish with spring onions. Serve hot, scraping up crispy rice crust.

recipes.name: Steamed Minced Pork with Salted Egg (Hom Yee Jing Yuk Beng)
recipes.description: A comforting home-style dish: minced pork patty steamed with salted egg yolk, soy sauce, and white pepper. Juicy, savory, and perfect with rice.
preparation: Mix minced pork with soy sauce, wine, pepper, sugar, cornstarch, and sesame oil. Spread evenly in a shallow dish.
Press salted egg yolk halves into the pork. Steam over high heat for 25–30 minutes until set and juicy.
Garnish with spring onions. Serve hot with rice.
tips: Use fatty pork for a juicier patty.
Add a little water to the pork mixture for extra tenderness.
recipes.source: Adapted from The Woks of Life, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore home kitchens.
steps: Mix minced pork with soy sauce, wine, pepper, sugar, cornstarch, and sesame oil. Spread evenly in a shallow dish.
Press salted egg yolk halves into the pork. Steam over high heat for 25–30 minutes until set and juicy.
Garnish with spring onions. Serve hot with rice.

recipes.name: Siew Mai (Pork and Shrimp Dumplings)
recipes.description: A classic Cantonese dim sum: open-faced dumplings filled with pork, shrimp, and mushrooms. Steamed and served with soy sauce or chili oil.
preparation: Mix all filling ingredients. Place a spoonful in each wrapper, shape into open dumplings.
Steam 8–10 minutes until cooked. Serve hot.
tips: Add a bit of crab roe for color.
Serve with chili oil or soy sauce.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dim sum restaurants.
steps: Mix all filling ingredients. Place a spoonful in each wrapper, shape into open dumplings.
Steam 8–10 minutes until cooked. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Har Gow (Shrimp Dumplings)
recipes.description: A dim sum favorite: translucent dumplings filled with shrimp and bamboo shoots, wrapped in a delicate wheat starch skin. Steamed and served hot.
preparation: Mix shrimp, bamboo, pork fat, and seasonings. Mix starches with boiling water to form a dough. Roll thin, fill with shrimp mixture, shape into dumplings.
Steam 6–8 minutes until translucent. Serve hot.
tips: Keep dough covered to prevent drying.
Serve with chili oil or soy sauce.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dim sum restaurants.
steps: Mix shrimp, bamboo, pork fat, and seasonings. Mix starches with boiling water to form a dough. Roll thin, fill with shrimp mixture, shape into dumplings.
Steam 6–8 minutes until translucent. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Chee Cheong Fun (Rice Noodle Rolls)
recipes.description: A Cantonese and local breakfast favorite: silky rice noodle rolls filled with shrimp, char siu, or plain, served with sweet soy sauce and sesame seeds.
preparation: Mix flours, water, and oil. Steam thin layers in a tray, add filling, roll up. Slice and serve with soy sauce and sesame seeds.
tips: Use a nonstick tray for easy rolling.
Serve warm for best texture.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dim sum stalls.
steps: Mix flours, water, and oil. Steam thin layers in a tray, add filling, roll up. Slice and serve with soy sauce and sesame seeds.

recipes.name: Xiao Long Bao (Soup Dumplings)
recipes.description: A Shanghai specialty: delicate dumplings filled with pork and a rich, savory soup. Steamed and served with black vinegar and ginger.
preparation: Mix pork, ginger, spring onions, seasonings, and stock. Place filling in wrappers, seal well.
Steam 8–10 minutes until cooked. Serve with black vinegar and ginger.
tips: Chill stock until firm for easy wrapping.
Serve hot for best soup texture.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dim sum restaurants.
steps: Mix pork, ginger, spring onions, seasonings, and stock. Place filling in wrappers, seal well.
Steam 8–10 minutes until cooked. Serve with black vinegar and ginger.

recipes.name: Chicken Feet (Phoenix Claws)
recipes.description: A dim sum classic: chicken feet deep-fried, then braised in a savory black bean sauce until tender. Served at dim sum restaurants and hawker stalls.
preparation: Deep-fry chicken feet until golden. Soak in cold water, then braise with sauces, garlic, ginger, and chili 1 hour until tender.
tips: Soak feet in ice water for a puffy texture.
Serve with extra chili for heat.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dim sum restaurants.
steps: Deep-fry chicken feet until golden. Soak in cold water, then braise with sauces, garlic, ginger, and chili 1 hour until tender.

recipes.name: Liu Sha Bao (Salted Egg Custard Buns)
recipes.description: A modern dim sum favorite: steamed buns filled with molten salted egg yolk custard. Soft, fluffy, and rich. Served at dim sum restaurants and bakeries.
preparation: Mix flour, yeast, sugar, and milk to form a dough. Let rise 1 hour. Mix filling ingredients. Divide dough, fill with custard, shape into buns. Steam 10–12 minutes.
tips: Use salted duck egg yolks for best flavor.
Serve warm for molten center.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dim sum bakeries.
steps: Mix flour, yeast, sugar, and milk to form a dough. Let rise 1 hour. Mix filling ingredients. Divide dough, fill with custard, shape into buns. Steam 10–12 minutes.

recipes.name: Wolfberry Osmanthus Jelly
recipes.description: A refreshing dim sum dessert: floral osmanthus jelly with wolfberries (goji berries). Served chilled at dim sum restaurants and dessert stalls.
preparation: Boil water, add osmanthus, goji, and rock sugar. Simmer 5 minutes. Stir in agar agar, dissolve. Pour into molds, chill until set.
tips: Use more osmanthus for stronger aroma.
Serve well chilled.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dessert stalls.
steps: Boil water, add osmanthus, goji, and rock sugar. Simmer 5 minutes. Stir in agar agar, dissolve. Pour into molds, chill until set.

recipes.name: Tofu Skin Rolls (Sin Juk Gyun)
recipes.description: A dim sum staple: beancurd skin rolls filled with pork, shrimp, and vegetables, steamed or fried. Served with soy sauce or chili.
preparation: Mix filling ingredients. Spread on beancurd skin, roll up and seal. Steam 10 minutes or fry until golden. Slice and serve.
tips: Serve with sweet soy sauce or chili dip.
Add bamboo shoots for crunch.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dim sum restaurants.
steps: Mix filling ingredients. Spread on beancurd skin, roll up and seal. Steam 10 minutes or fry until golden. Slice and serve.

recipes.name: Sesame Balls (Jian Dui)
recipes.description: A popular dim sum and snack: deep-fried glutinous rice balls filled with sweet red bean paste, coated in sesame seeds. Crispy outside, chewy inside.
preparation: Mix flour, sugar, and water to form a dough. Wrap dough around red bean paste, roll into balls, coat with sesame seeds. Fry until golden.
tips: Keep oil at medium heat for even frying.
Serve warm for best texture.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore bakeries.
steps: Mix flour, sugar, and water to form a dough. Wrap dough around red bean paste, roll into balls, coat with sesame seeds. Fry until golden.

recipes.name: Shrimp Stuffed Eggplants
recipes.description: A dim sum and zi char favorite: eggplant slices stuffed with shrimp paste, pan-fried and served with savory sauce. Popular at hawker stalls and dim sum restaurants.
preparation: Mix shrimp, spring onions, soy, pepper, and cornstarch. Sandwich between eggplant slices. Pan-fry until golden. Simmer sauce ingredients, pour over eggplant.
tips: Use long eggplants for easy stuffing.
Serve with steamed rice.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore zi char stalls.
steps: Mix shrimp, spring onions, soy, pepper, and cornstarch. Sandwich between eggplant slices. Pan-fry until golden. Simmer sauce ingredients, pour over eggplant.

recipes.name: Red Bean Pancake (Wo Bing)
recipes.description: A dim sum and snack favorite: crispy pan-fried pancakes filled with sweet red bean paste. Served at dim sum restaurants and bakeries.
preparation: Mix flour, sugar, and water to form a dough. Roll out, fill with red bean paste, fold and seal. Pan-fry until golden, sprinkle with sesame seeds.
tips: Serve warm for best flavor.
Add more sesame seeds for aroma.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore bakeries.
steps: Mix flour, sugar, and water to form a dough. Roll out, fill with red bean paste, fold and seal. Pan-fry until golden, sprinkle with sesame seeds.

recipes.name: Sugar Cane Prawn
recipes.description: A festive dim sum and zi char dish: shrimp paste molded around sugar cane sticks, steamed or fried. Sweet, savory, and aromatic.
preparation: Mix shrimp, pork fat, spring onions, garlic, soy, pepper, and cornstarch. Mold around sugar cane sticks. Steam 8 minutes or fry until golden. Serve hot.
tips: Use fresh sugar cane for best aroma.
Serve with sweet chili sauce.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore zi char stalls.
steps: Mix shrimp, pork fat, spring onions, garlic, soy, pepper, and cornstarch. Mold around sugar cane sticks. Steam 8 minutes or fry until golden. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Malay Steamed Cake (Ma Lai Gao)
recipes.description: A soft, fluffy Cantonese steamed cake with caramel flavor. Served at dim sum restaurants and bakeries in Singapore.
preparation: Beat eggs and sugar until pale. Add milk, oil, water, then flour, baking powder, and soda. Pour into a lined pan, steam 30 minutes until set.
tips: Let batter rest for a fluffier cake.
Serve warm for best texture.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dim sum bakeries.
steps: Beat eggs and sugar until pale. Add milk, oil, water, then flour, baking powder, and soda. Pour into a lined pan, steam 30 minutes until set.

recipes.name: Ban Mian (Handmade Noodles)
recipes.description: A hawker favorite: handmade wheat noodles served in a savory broth with pork, egg, vegetables, and anchovies. Popular at food courts and noodle stalls in Singapore.
preparation: Mix flour, egg, salt, and water to form a dough. Rest 30 minutes, roll and cut into noodles.
Cook noodles in boiling water. Simmer stock, add pork, vegetables, garlic, and soy. Add noodles, top with egg and fried ikan bilis. Serve hot.
tips: Use a pasta machine for even noodles.
Add chili for extra heat.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore noodle stalls.
steps: Mix flour, egg, salt, and water to form a dough. Rest 30 minutes, roll and cut into noodles.
Cook noodles in boiling water. Simmer stock, add pork, vegetables, garlic, and soy. Add noodles, top with egg and fried ikan bilis. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Beef Kway Teow (Beef Hor Fun)
recipes.description: A classic Singaporean hawker dish: silky flat rice noodles stir-fried with tender beef slices, bean sprouts, and a savory black bean sauce.
preparation: Marinate beef with 1/2 the soy sauces, cornstarch, and water for 10 minutes.
Heat oil, fry garlic, add beef, stir-fry until just cooked. Remove.
Add more oil, fry noodles, add sauces, toss. Return beef, add bean sprouts and spring onions. Serve hot.
tips: Use high heat for wok hei.
Do not overcook beef.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore hawker stalls.
steps: Marinate beef with 1/2 the soy sauces, cornstarch, and water for 10 minutes.
Heat oil, fry garlic, add beef, stir-fry until just cooked. Remove.
Add more oil, fry noodles, add sauces, toss. Return beef, add bean sprouts and spring onions. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Curry Chicken Noodles
recipes.description: A comforting bowl of yellow noodles in a rich, spicy coconut curry broth with chicken, tau pok, and potatoes. A hawker favourite.
preparation: Blend curry paste. Fry in oil until fragrant.
Add chicken, brown. Add potatoes, stock, coconut milk, salt, and sugar. Simmer until chicken and potatoes are cooked.
Blanch noodles, place in bowls. Ladle curry, add tau pok. Serve hot.
tips: Add bean sprouts for crunch.
Use fresh curry paste for best flavor.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore hawker stalls.
steps: Blend curry paste. Fry in oil until fragrant.
Add chicken, brown. Add potatoes, stock, coconut milk, salt, and sugar. Simmer until chicken and potatoes are cooked.
Blanch noodles, place in bowls. Ladle curry, add tau pok. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Orh Kueh (Steamed Yam Cake)
recipes.description: A savory steamed cake made with yam, rice flour, and dried shrimp, topped with fried shallots and spring onions. Popular as a breakfast or snack.
preparation: Fry shallots in oil, set aside. Fry yam and dried shrimp in remaining oil.
Mix flours, water, salt, and pepper. Add yam mixture. Pour into greased tray.
Steam 1 hour until set. Cool, slice, and top with fried shallots and spring onions.
tips: Serve with chili sauce.
Add Chinese sausage for variation.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore hawker stalls.
steps: Fry shallots in oil, set aside. Fry yam and dried shrimp in remaining oil.
Mix flours, water, salt, and pepper. Add yam mixture. Pour into greased tray.
Steam 1 hour until set. Cool, slice, and top with fried shallots and spring onions.

recipes.name: Sliced Fish Soup in Milky Broth
recipes.description: A light, nourishing soup of fresh fish slices in a milky, peppery broth with vegetables and tofu. A hawker and home-cooked favourite.
preparation: Heat oil, fry ginger. Add water, bring to boil. Add fish, tofu, tomato, mustard greens, salt, and pepper. Simmer 10 minutes.
Add evaporated milk, simmer 2 minutes. Garnish with spring onions. Serve hot.
tips: Use fresh fish for best flavor.
Add lettuce or seaweed for variation.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore hawker stalls.
steps: Heat oil, fry ginger. Add water, bring to boil. Add fish, tofu, tomato, mustard greens, salt, and pepper. Simmer 10 minutes.
Add evaporated milk, simmer 2 minutes. Garnish with spring onions. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Har Cheong Kai (Prawn Paste Fried Chicken)
recipes.description: A beloved Singaporean zi char dish: chicken wings marinated in fermented prawn paste, then deep-fried until crispy and fragrant.
preparation: Marinate chicken with prawn paste, egg, sugar, and pepper for at least 2 hours.
Coat with rice flour and cornstarch. Deep fry until golden and crispy. Drain and serve hot.
tips: Marinate overnight for deeper flavor.
Serve with lime wedges.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore zi char stalls.
steps: Marinate chicken with prawn paste, egg, sugar, and pepper for at least 2 hours.
Coat with rice flour and cornstarch. Deep fry until golden and crispy. Drain and serve hot.

recipes.name: Chilled Tofu with Century Egg and Pickles
recipes.description: A refreshing cold dish: silken tofu topped with diced century egg, pickled vegetables, and a savory soy dressing. Popular at Chinese restaurants and home tables.
preparation: Place tofu on a serving plate. Top with century egg and pickles.
Drizzle with soy sauce and sesame oil. Garnish with spring onions and fried shallots. Serve cold.
tips: Use soft silken tofu for best texture.
Add chili oil for a spicy kick.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore home kitchens.
steps: Place tofu on a serving plate. Top with century egg and pickles.
Drizzle with soy sauce and sesame oil. Garnish with spring onions and fried shallots. Serve cold.

recipes.name: Duck Roll Tempura
recipes.description: A creative fusion dish: shredded duck wrapped in beancurd skin, battered and deep-fried tempura-style. Crispy outside, juicy inside.
preparation: Place duck and spring onions on beancurd skin, roll up tightly.
Dip in tempura batter, deep fry until golden and crisp. Drain and slice. Serve hot.
tips: Seal rolls with a flour paste.
Serve with sweet chili sauce.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore zi char stalls.
steps: Place duck and spring onions on beancurd skin, roll up tightly.
Dip in tempura batter, deep fry until golden and crisp. Drain and slice. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Char Siew (BBQ Pork)
recipes.description: A Cantonese classic: pork shoulder marinated in a sweet-savory sauce, roasted until caramelized and tender. A staple at Chinese roast meat stalls.
preparation: Marinate pork with all sauces and spices for at least 4 hours.
Roast at 200°C for 30–40 minutes, basting occasionally. Slice and serve.
tips: Use pork belly for a fattier version.
Baste with honey for extra glaze.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore roast meat stalls.
steps: Marinate pork with all sauces and spices for at least 4 hours.
Roast at 200°C for 30–40 minutes, basting occasionally. Slice and serve.

recipes.name: Crispy Roast Pork (Siu Yuk)
recipes.description: A Cantonese favourite: pork belly roasted until the skin is shatteringly crisp, with juicy, flavorful meat. Served at roast meat stalls and festive occasions.
preparation: Score pork skin, rub meat side with five spice, pepper, and wine. Rub salt on skin. Marinate 2 hours.
Roast at 220°C for 30 minutes, then 250°C for 20–30 minutes until skin is crisp. Rest, slice, and serve.
tips: Prick skin all over for maximum crispiness.
Roast on a rack for even heat.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore roast meat stalls.
steps: Score pork skin, rub meat side with five spice, pepper, and wine. Rub salt on skin. Marinate 2 hours.
Roast at 220°C for 30 minutes, then 250°C for 20–30 minutes until skin is crisp. Rest, slice, and serve.

recipes.name: Vinegar Pork Trotters (Zhu Jiao Cu)
recipes.description: A traditional Chinese dish of pork trotters braised in sweet black vinegar, ginger, and eggs. Rich, tangy, and nourishing—especially popular as a confinement dish.
steps: Blanch pork trotters in boiling water for 5 minutes. Drain and rinse.
Heat oil in a large pot. Fry ginger slices until fragrant and slightly browned.
Add pork trotters and stir-fry for 2–3 minutes.
Add black vinegar, water, rock sugar, soy sauces, and Shaoxing wine. Bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer.
Cover and simmer for 1.5–2 hours until pork is tender.
Add hard-boiled eggs in the last 30 minutes of cooking.
Adjust seasoning with salt and more sugar or vinegar to taste.
Serve hot, with rice.
tips: Use old ginger for a stronger, warming flavor.
The dish tastes even better the next day as flavors develop.
Add more eggs if desired—they soak up the delicious sauce!
recipes.source: Adapted from Singapore/Malaysia Chinese home cook recipes.
recipes.origin: Vinegar Pork Trotters is a traditional Chinese dish, especially popular for postpartum recovery and festive occasions.

ingredient_breakdown.ingredient: sweet black vinegar (Chan Kong Thye or similar)

recipes.name: Sweet and Sour Pork (Gu Lou Yuk)
recipes.description: A Cantonese classic: crispy pork pieces tossed in a tangy, sweet, and savory sauce with pineapple, peppers, and onions. A favorite at Chinese restaurants and zi char stalls.

sauce.cornstarch: 1 tsp (mixed with 1 tbsp water, for thickening)

steps: Marinate pork with salt, pepper, Shaoxing wine, egg, and 4 tbsp cornstarch for 15 minutes.
Dredge pork pieces in extra cornstarch. Deep fry in hot oil (170°C/340°F) until golden and crispy. Drain on paper towels.
In a bowl, mix all sauce ingredients except cornstarch slurry.
Heat 1 tbsp oil in a wok. Stir-fry onion and peppers for 1 minute. Add pineapple, fry briefly.
Pour in sauce, bring to a simmer. Add cornstarch slurry and cook until thickened and glossy.
Add fried pork, toss quickly to coat. Serve immediately.
tips: Use pork shoulder for juicier, more tender pieces.
Fry pork twice for extra crispiness.
Adjust sugar and vinegar to taste for your preferred balance.
recipes.source: Adapted from Singapore zi char, Cantonese home cook, and restaurant recipes.
recipes.origin: Sweet and Sour Pork is a Cantonese classic, now a favorite at Chinese restaurants worldwide.

recipes.name: Sweet and Sour Fish (Tang Cu Yu)
recipes.description: A zi char and restaurant favorite: crispy fried fish fillets or whole fish, tossed in a tangy, sweet, and savory sauce with pineapple, peppers, and onions.

main.white fish fillets (e.g., tilapia, snapp: 400g, cut into large chunks (or 1 whole fish, cleaned and scored)

sauce.cornstarch: 1 tsp (mixed with 1 tbsp water, for thickening)

steps: Marinate fish with salt, pepper, Shaoxing wine, egg, and 4 tbsp cornstarch for 10–15 minutes.
Dredge fish pieces in extra cornstarch. Deep fry in hot oil (170°C/340°F) until golden and crispy. Drain on paper towels.
In a bowl, mix all sauce ingredients except cornstarch slurry.
Heat 1 tbsp oil in a wok. Stir-fry onion and peppers for 1 minute. Add pineapple, fry briefly.
Pour in sauce, bring to a simmer. Add cornstarch slurry and cook until thickened and glossy.
Add fried fish, toss gently to coat. Serve immediately.
tips: Use firm white fish for best texture.
Fry fish twice for extra crispiness.
Adjust sugar and vinegar to taste for your preferred balance.
recipes.source: Adapted from Singapore zi char, Cantonese home cook, and restaurant recipes.
recipes.origin: Sweet and Sour Fish is a Cantonese classic, now a favorite at Chinese restaurants and zi char stalls worldwide.

ingredient_breakdown.ingredient: white fish fillets (e.g., tilapia, snapper, seabass)

recipes.name: Stir-Fried Bittergourd with Egg (Ku Gua Chao Dan)
recipes.description: A classic Chinese home-style stir-fry: tender, slightly bitter gourd slices tossed with fluffy scrambled eggs. Nutritious, quick, and comforting.

main.bittergourd (bitter melon): 1 medium (about 250g), halved, seeded, and thinly sliced

steps: Slice bittergourd thinly. Rub with 1/2 tsp salt, let sit 10 minutes, then rinse and squeeze dry (to reduce bitterness).
Heat oil in a wok or pan. Sauté garlic until fragrant.
Add bittergourd, stir-fry 2–3 minutes until just tender.
Season with salt, white pepper, soy sauce, and sugar (if using).
Push bittergourd to the side, add a little more oil if needed. Pour in beaten eggs.
Let eggs set slightly, then scramble and mix with bittergourd. Stir-fry until eggs are just cooked and still soft.
Serve hot, garnished with spring onions if desired.
tips: Do not overcook eggs; they should remain soft and fluffy.
Rubbing and rinsing bittergourd with salt helps reduce bitterness.
Add sliced chili for a spicy kick.
recipes.source: Adapted from Singapore/Malaysia Chinese home cook recipes.
recipes.origin: Stir-Fried Bittergourd with Egg is a staple in Chinese households and zi char stalls.

recipes.name: Stir-Fried Long Beans with Dried Shrimp (Gan Bian Si Ji Dou)
recipes.description: A classic Chinese home-style and zi char dish: crisp-tender long beans stir-fried with aromatic dried shrimp, garlic, and a touch of chili. Savory, umami, and perfect with rice.
steps: Heat oil in a wok or large pan over medium heat. Add dried shrimp and stir-fry until fragrant and lightly crispy (about 1 minute).
Add garlic and chili, stir-fry until aromatic.
Add long beans, increase heat to high, and stir-fry for 2–3 minutes until beans are bright green and just tender.
Add soy sauce, oyster sauce, sugar, and white pepper. Stir-fry another 1–2 minutes until well coated and beans are cooked but still crisp.
Taste and adjust seasoning if needed. Serve hot as a side dish.
tips: For extra flavor, soak dried shrimp in warm water for 5 minutes, then drain before using.
Do not overcook long beans—they should remain crisp-tender.
Add a splash of water if pan gets too dry during stir-frying.
recipes.source: Adapted from Singapore/Malaysia Chinese home cook and zi char recipes.
recipes.origin: Stir-Fried Long Beans with Dried Shrimp is a staple in Chinese households and zi char stalls across Singapore.

recipes.name: Steamed Egg Custard (Chawanmushi-style Chinese Egg)
recipes.description: A classic Chinese home-style dish: silky, savory steamed egg custard, gently cooked to a delicate, just-set texture. Comforting, nutritious, and perfect with rice.
steps: Crack eggs into a bowl. Add water or stock, soy sauce, salt, and white pepper. Beat gently with chopsticks or a fork until just combined (do not whisk to foam).
Strain the egg mixture through a fine sieve into a heatproof dish or individual bowls for extra smoothness.
Cover dish(es) with foil or a plate to prevent water droplets from falling in.
Steam over gently simmering water (not a rolling boil) for 12–15 minutes, or until just set but still jiggly in the center.
Remove from steamer. Drizzle with a few drops of sesame oil and garnish with spring onions if desired. Serve hot or warm.
tips: The ideal egg-to-liquid ratio is about 1:1.5 by volume for a silky texture.
Use low, gentle heat for steaming to avoid bubbles or a tough texture.
Add toppings like minced pork, shrimp, mushrooms, or century egg for variety.
Let the custard rest a minute before serving for the smoothest texture.
recipes.source: Adapted from Singapore/Malaysia Chinese home cook recipes.
recipes.origin: Steamed Egg Custard is a beloved comfort dish in Chinese households, often served as part of a family meal or for children and elders.
